title: 110_hr1944
content: The Act titled "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" introduces screening, rehabilitation, and treatment for traumatic brain injury under a new subchapter in Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code. The Act "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" establishes a screening program for eligible veterans to screen for symptoms of traumatic brain injury. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress with information on the number of veterans screened, prevalence of symptoms, and recommendations for improving care. The Act "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" establishes a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation for eligible veterans who served in combat operations. The program includes residential, community, and home-based components at four designated polytrauma network sites. Eligible veterans must be otherwise eligible for care under this chapter. The "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" establishes a program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation for eligible veterans who served in combat operations. Eligible veterans must have moderate to severe traumatic brain injury and require supervision for daily activities. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress detailing the program's operation and the number of veterans receiving care. The Secretary is mandated to establish traumatic brain injury transition offices at Department polytrauma network sites to coordinate healthcare and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. These offices can arrange for healthcare and services through cooperative agreements with public or private entities offering long-term neurobehavioral rehabilitation programs. The Secretary is required to establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry for individuals who served in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom and exhibit symptoms of traumatic brain injury. This registry will contain the names of those seeking care or filing claims related to their service. The Secretary is mandated to establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry for individuals who served in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom. The registry will include relevant medical data and information with the individual's permission or if deceased. Individuals listed will be notified of significant research developments on the health consequences of military service in these theaters of operations. The chapter is amended by adding new items at the end. Subchapter IX of title 38, United States Code, addresses traumatic brain injury with provisions for screening, long-term rehabilitation programs, transition offices, and a registry. The Secretary must implement these requirements within 180 days of the enactment of the Act.
